> Still not shaken by anger=

emper, Tucson continues his poetic interlude with artful grace and a sense =
of undisturbed tranquility. =A0His arms and hands follow the flow of water =
that jets out of the fissures.  Yet the water simply follows the flow of hi=
s arms rather than splashing on them.  And with the water came the compulsi=
on to transform into his beast form.   And then as warrior once again becam=
e the dragon, he embraces the element of water and melds with its own natur=
al forces and then, with his powerful tail, he strikes the wall, attempting=

> 
> Fire may not have been his =
theme but he embraces something far more significant than simple flames.  T=
he element of Thunder, and lightning and the raging torrent of rain water t=
hat follows the first clap of thunder.  He gives a draconic roar that sends=

>

o his enemies.

> " Fire may be powerful and capable of massive damage, y=
et fire is not the most formidable element of nature.  For it has a weaknes=
s, water.  And even more powerful than water, is the storm that spawns it. =
 Embrace the power of the storm, be at one with the tempest, and bring fort=
h the light that follows darkness. "
> 
> Tucson's armor shimmers as the gl=
int on each metallic scale flashes like lightning. He stands his ground and=
 begins moving his wings, kicking up a slight breeze in the cave.

am the storm, and I will not be easily stopped.  Your darkness will see lig=
